Text: Hiyaah!
Hah!
(With that, we start training.)

(We suppress our magic through meditation
before practicing our swings and going over the
basics of swordplay.)

(Nice, nice. I'm all for reviewing the basics.
They're important to know. In section nine,
we'd wave our swords for a few seconds
and play-fight the whole time.)

(It's nice to see the strongest fighters value their
fundamentals. Plus, all the students are skilled.
I can say it's a neat environment—and I'm not
trying to suck up or anything.)

(And most importantly, the techniques taught in this
class are hyper-logical.)

(It feels great to take part in training that doesn't
leave me bored out of my mind.)
Hoo!
What...?!
(We pick up our swords and start exchanging blows.)
Hyah!
(I swing, and she blocks. She strikes, and I guard.)

(We don't hit each other, moving at a sluggish pace,
and skimp on magical energy...)

(All around us, the other pairs are locked head-to-
head in all-out fights, blasting each other with spells.)
(But to my surprise, Alexia is matching my pace.)
(No. That's not it...)

(Maybe this is normal for her. After all, the purpose
of sparring is to review our strategies, meaning that
speed and power are pointless.)

(Alexia is focused on this goal—making an honest
review of techniques and reversals.)

(Come to think of it, Alexia made a comment when she
saw me stretching before class.)
Interesting.
(Then she started copying my stretches.)

(As I spar with her, I think she's good. She adheres
to the basics and grasps the foundations of combat.)
(But it feels uninspired. Yeah, it's run-of-the-mill.)

(People generally say she's inferior to her sister,
who many consider to be the strongest combatant
in the kingdom.)
Hah!

(But that's the fruit of her labor—her swordplay is
polished, refined, and devoid of excess.)

(That's the proof that she's mastered the basics
step-by-step.)
(Delta, you could learn a thing or two from her.)

(I engage in a fake conversation with one
certain therianthrope girl—one whose
swordsmanship I find hard to forgive.)
...Okay, that'll be all for today's class.
Thank you.
Thank you!
Your swordplay isn't bad.
Thanks.
But I don't like it.
(She likes lifting me up to bring me down.)
It's like I'm watching myself fight.
...Huh.

(She begins packing up, leaving it at that. Class is
over.)

(Never in my wildest dreams did I expect to get
through this elective without a hitch.)

(If I can just get my stuff together, change, and
dash to my dorm room, I might be able to—)

(My plans are interrupted when I eavesdrop on Alexia
and Mr. Zenon talking.)
I am guessing this is your answer, Alexia.
(Mr. Zenon says this coolly.)
Yes, that's right.
I've decided to go out with him, "Instructor" Zenon.

Jeez, you're like a kid. You can't keep running
forever.
(Mr. Zenon is calm and collected.)

I'm just a kid. This situation is too grown-up for
me.
(Alexia replies.)
(Ah, I see. So that's why she brought me here.)

While it hasn't been made public yet, you're my
fiancé—
You're just a suitor—it's still not a done deal.
That will change once you consent.

I'll decide for myself who I marry, thank you very
much.
(The situation all makes sense now.)
(Not that I hadn't mostly figured it out,)

(how I got into this section and why she chose to go
out with me.)

(Watching their cutscene play out and melting into
the background, I pray these two protagonists won't
drag me into their drama.)
Want to stop by Mitsugoshi on the way back?
Sounds good.

(While these sorts of stock conversations drift in the
background of the courtyard after school...)

You needed a stand-in because you don't want to
be engaged to Mr. Zenon?

So that's why you chose a low-level aristocrat like
me.
(Alexia and I confront each other.)
Yes, that's right.
He's not my fiancé, just one of my suitors.

(Alexia says this while looking all calm and
composed.)
It's the same thing.

It's not. He keeps pressing the issue as if it's a
done deal, and it's stressing me out.
That has nothing to do with me.

I hate to break it to you, but I'm tired of all the
looks, and I have no plans to get sucked into
this mess.
...You're awfully cold, for a "boyfriend."
A lover only in name, right?
But that goes for both of us, doesn't it?
Mr. I-Confessed-To-a-Girl-On-a-Dare, Cid Kagenou.
Huh?!
(Alright, hold on. Let me regain my composure.)
(It's okay. I'm totally calm.)

I have no idea what you're talking about. Do you have
any proof?

(Right, evidence first. As long as the guys didn't
stab me in the back, it won't matter how
suspicious she is of my intentions...)
I think their names were Skel and Po.

When I approached your friends, they turned bright
red and blabbed everything, including things I didn't
ask about.

How cruel to play with the heart and purity of a
maiden.

If everyone were to find out, you might never be able
to return to the peaceful school life you once knew.
Nice friends you've got there.

(I imagine myself beating up Skel and turning Po into
a pile of mashed potatoes to regain my mental
composure.)

Are you alright? What's with the super twisted look
on your face?

I'm fine. If I look twisted it's because it reflects
my personality. But I'm not as bad as you.
Hmm? Did you say something?
Nothing.

(I have no choice but to accept defeat. My fatal
flaw is choosing the wrong friends.)
Well...

(Alexia turns her back on me with a huff and puffs
out her chest.)

Let's keep pretending we're together for now—until
that man gives up.
Will he, though? I'm not enough to stop him.

I know. I just need to buy time. I'll figure
something out.
I've got a bad feeling about this.
...Stop whining.

(Alexia fishes a coin out of her pocket and tosses it
into the air.)
(This coin is worth ten thousand zeni!!!)
...What?
Do I look like I'd be swayed by cash?
You do.
Heh...
Absolutely.
(I say from all fours, carefully retrieving the coin.)

(Alexia again reaches into her pocket, retrieves a
coin, and flings it into the air.)
Awooo!!!

(The allowance from my parents isn't enough to fund
my shadowbroker activities.)
(I'm not missing out on this opportunity.)
Good doggy.

(I look up at Alexia, and her red eyes bear down on
me.)
(I can see up her pleated skirt.)
Are you going to do as I say?
(She asks with a grin that oozes wickedness.)
Of course.
(I smile from ear to ear.)
Huff, huff, huff...
Woof!
Go fetch.

(Alexia pats my head before briskly walking away with
her short skirt billowing behind her.)

(And so I decide to continue my "relationship" with
Alexia.)
